body: @tqchen

Your figure looks reasonable to me.
The error seems strange. Could you give a minimal script that reproduce this error?

there are several things that can be done to speed things up.
- Use openblas, which support multi-threading
- Use NaiveEngine, that eliminates the thread scheduling

@tqchen thanks a lot for the help! 
 I used openblas with USE_OPENMP = 1  and used naive engine which speeded things up :)  The prediction now takes 0.55 seconds for a single image.

I have a few more questions - 
1. I want to make predictions for a batch of 8 images using imagenet-21k-inception model in under a second in cpu mode. Is that possible?
2. In the documentation of the predict api (http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/doxygen/c__predict__api_8h.html) it is written that num_input_nodes = 1 for feedforward.
   How can batching be done for feedforward prediction and will batching speed things up?

It is not necessary to implement this as a template. For example, softmax implement this as a function. The expression is only needed when you want to do something like pipeline up expressions. Alternatively, you can simply implement the functions just in mxnet by calling cuFFT and FFTW separately by reference the implementation of CuDNN operators

https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/blob/master/mshadow/tensor.h#L649

I agree that explicitly having handle is always better. As closure should not be treated as function. 

@mli As long as we make sure the old calls to server works, I think this change is fine.

When you create the operator, change the input shape to include batch dimension should enable batching. i.e.
instead of

`(1, channel, height, width)` change it to  `(batch_size, channel, height, width)`

Yah, the explicit handle makes front-end rely on pure C api.

BTW, since @piiswrong suggested to make it a new name, I haven't update this PR. I'm trying to figure out what is the most natural way to run the KVStoreServer, which is related to arguments this function takes, according to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1637

keeping the same name should be fine.

This is not a mxnet problem but an opencv problem.
Try download the correct version of ippicv by yourself and move the `libippicv.a` to your opencv library path.
Which kvstores is this affecting? Only the "*_cpu" ones?
Ans it is implemented based on the python version.

In the provided file symbol_squeezenet.py the variable `num_classes` is not used;
should it be put in  `conv10` module as `num_filter=1000`?

Moreover, in this version the output size is 9000, but the classes are only 1000!
I think that the global average method

> http://arxiv.org/abs/1312.4400

should be implemented as a `mx.symbol.GlobalAveragePooling` symbol or as an option of `mx.symbol.Pooling`
OK, this time let's keep the same name.

The bottleneck is on the computation then. Using cpp interface won't speed things up. You can, however, try NaiveEngine. Note that 21k-inception is a bigger net than normal inception used in imagenet, so the speed could be justified

vote 2. cloning notebook could be a problem especially the network is not so great (such as at china). but recommend to have script in notebook to install mxnet and start the notebook service, so that anyone can view and run the notebook in browser, just as what we did for gtc.

don't think it's necessary to have a separate example repo. but i do recommend to clean the example folder.
vote 2
Vote 2. It will take a very long time to recursively clone the repo if include them as submodule. Providing a link to users should be enough.

i added a test case for training with various kvstores #1826 , they should give very similar results if we try to eliminate randomness. however, i observed that cpu and gpu give quite different results even if the inputs are identical. 
- local: both gradients are averaged and parameters are updated on cpu
- device: both are done at gpu

so if you 
- disable cudnn
- disable all randomness in data iterator,  for example

``` python
train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = "data/cifar/train.rec",
        mean_img    = "data/cifar/cifar_mean.bin",
        data_shape  = input_shape,
        batch_size  = batch_size,
        rand_crop   = False,
        rand_mirror = False,
        shuffle     = False,
        round_batch = False,
        num_parts   = num_parts,
        part_index  = part_index)
    val = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = "data/cifar/test.rec",
        mean_img    = "data/cifar/cifar_mean.bin",
        rand_crop   = False,
        rand_mirror = False,
        shuffle     = False,
        round_batch = False,
        data_shape  = input_shape,
        batch_size  = batch_size)
    return (train, val)
```
- increase the batch size to reduce the number of iterations

both local and device should give similar results on epoch 1.

Vote 2. The notebooks already exist in history, so moving does not help speeding up cloning unless the user explicitly do shallow clone. But it is still good to separate notebooks as the history diff usually is not very interpretable.

I would prefer to keep the other examples in the main repo. While notebooks can be directly viewed online, the examples needs to be downloaded to run. Having them in the main repo makes it convenient for user to try them out.

@rollingstone ok, i'll try it today
Are you accessing the output tensor with the same shape of input?
nice catch, fixed by the latest change

My experience is that if you have 2 gpus, it goes to _update_params_kvstore. And arglist is the list maintaining all layers parameter, each element in arg_list will have 2 elements with respect 2 gpus in your case. grad_list is the same as arglist but storing gradient date. The _update_params_kvstore only runs once per iteration. The gradients are summed up(or averaging,I can't remember clearly) in kvstore before passing to optimizer, where the weight is updated.
This one is not _update_params_kvstore. It is the other one without using kvstore.

And in lstm.py, I found that you copy the row of train_data into seq_data, which has size of (20, 1) and words in that row  does not come from the same sentence. Are you using each row of them training?
If you find it a bug, I would love to fix it. @tqchen
Oh...I get your point. I think you are right. And I have question now. Are these weights synchronized in this case? It looks like that each device is updated in turns.

detect_cuDNN is in mshadow/cmake/Cuda.cmake,
Do you init and pull submodule "mshadow"?

Now all the three example runs (mnist, cifar, lstm). Basically now `Module` serves as a drop-in replacement of `FeedForward`. Except its internal is re-factored, so for example, now `BucketingModule` can utilize `score`, `prediction`, etc. automatically.

One important thing that I left out is distributed training. Because I do not have environment to test, I'm postponing this. Or maybe @mli could add the functionality later on. But I am expecting the old `FeedForward` module to co-exist for a long time. So should not be a big problem for now.

Original plan was to add a stochastic depth example with this. But it seems weights-copying might be a better way, as was suggested at GTC.
The summation happens inside kvstore before applying the updater. Then the weight is pulled back to device local parameter by kvstore.pull

@antinucleon Do we have the same speed as torch when running on PTB? One potential factor for slowness that @tqchen noticed is that we do embedding separately for each time index, as oppose to doing them all at once and splitting.

great work, thanks! a naive question: will it be easy to get module to implement 
- model parallelism for multiple gpu in a single machine 
- data parallelism over multiple machines with model parallelism in a single machine.

```
def _update_params(param_arrays, grad_arrays, updater, num_device,
                   kvstore=None):
    """ Perform update of param_arrays from grad_arrays not on kvstore."""
    for index, pair in enumerate(zip(param_arrays, grad_arrays)):
        arg_list, grad_list = pair
        if grad_list[0] is None:
            continue
        if kvstore:
            # push gradient, priority is negative index
            kvstore.push(index, grad_list, priority=-index)
            # pull back the sum gradients, to the same locations.
            kvstore.pull(index, grad_list, priority=-index)
        for k, p in enumerate(zip(arg_list, grad_list)):
            # faked an index here, to make optimizer create diff
            # state for the same index but on diff devs, TODO(mli)
            # use a better solution latter
            w, g = p
            updater(index*num_device+k, g, w)
```

What if the kvstore is None? So there is no push and pull. it seems there is nothing for synchronising the weights. The updater seems to update parameters on each gpu separately. @tqchen
okay thanks :) @tqchen

@mli it depends on how do you want to implement it. If you want to use symbolic API, then it is the same as before (as @tqchen 's example shows, we use attributes to hint which part should be computed on which gpu). What module api makes it easier is imperative api. For example, (after we add some sequential container module) we can define two parts of the network directly as two different symbols and the container will be able to chain the two modules, so model parallel is implemented.

In general imperative API will be slightly less efficient because memory optimization can only be carried within one atomic module. And there will be state copying cost. But I guess for model parallel those cannot be avoided even with pure symbolic API.

@tqchen @pluskid
I'm sorry I missed a important reason why is neuraltalk2 is fast.
In neuraltalk2, input consists one images and five correspond sentences. CNN only forward one time and a feature expand layer repeatedly expands features to number of correspond sentence, which causes that even batch size is m but get about speed of five times fast.
In my implementation, I divide (image, 5 captions) pair to (image, caption) pair in order to handle different length buckets, and it makes my implementation slow.
Sorry for myself's miss, I'll rewrite it and make a another PR. Thanks :)

Ps, some test data on single Titan Black
- Fixed cnn, without changing environment variable and LSTM length 16, speed is about 500 samples/s.
- Fixed cnn, with changing environment variable and LSTM length 16, speed is about 440 samples/s. The environment variable influences speed definitely. @piiswrong 
- NeuralTalk2 speed, with feature expands, is about 14.5 (image, 5 \* captions) pairs/s.

`train_iter.reset()`
I think this function is only called when you have 1gpu on 1 machine. Try printing sth in your experiment should be helpful.

@piiswrong @pluskid 
I wrote a simple LSTM implementation script:
- The LSTM layer module is `lstm_layer`, and `lstm_layer_init_states()` is a function to get `init_states` for data iterator.
- The DataIter `simple_data_iterator` generates data and labels: `label = np.ones` and `data = label + np.random.normal`.
  - `fea_len` is the feature length, `bucket_num` is the bucket number, `batch_size` is the utterance parallel number, `max_seq_len` is the maximum sequence length of all utterances.
  - `order` controls the way `simple_data_iterator` selects bucket when called `next()`: 
  - When `order = 'ascend'`, `bucket_key` is set **from 1 to `max_seq_len`**,
  - When `order = 'descend'`, `bucket_key` is set from **`max_seq_len` to 1**, 
  - When `order = random`, `bucket_key` is set in random order. 
  - `simple_data_iterator.next()` changes bucket_key according to `order` and returns one `simple_batch` each time. 
- I built a 3 LSTM layers network, each LSTM layer has 256 hidden nodes, I change `max_seq_len`, `bucket_num` and `order` in experiments.
- Here is my script:

``` python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""
Created on Tue Apr 12 17:32:32 2016

@author: zxlee
"""
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np
from collections import namedtuple

LSTMState = namedtuple("LSTMState", ["c", "h"])
LSTMParam = namedtuple("LSTMParam", ["i2h_weight", "i2h_bias",
                                     "h2h_weight", "h2h_bias"])

''' one lstm cell '''                                     
def lstm_cell(indata, prev_state, param, num_hidden, cell_idx, layer_name, dropout=0.):
    if dropout > 0.:
        indata = mx.sym.Dropout(data=indata, p=dropout)
    i2h = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=indata,
                                weight=param.i2h_weight,
                                bias=param.i2h_bias,
                                num_hidden=num_hidden * 4,
                                name="%s_t%d_i2h" % (layer_name, cell_idx))
    h2h = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=prev_state.h,
                            weight=param.h2h_weight,
                            bias=param.h2h_bias,
                            num_hidden=num_hidden * 4,
                            name="%s_t%d_h2h" % (layer_name, cell_idx))
    gates = i2h + h2h

    slice_gates = mx.sym.SliceChannel(gates, num_outputs=4,
                                      name="%s_t%d_slice" % (layer_name, cell_idx))
    in_gate = mx.sym.Activation(slice_gates[0], act_type="sigmoid")
    in_transform = mx.sym.Activation(slice_gates[1], act_type="tanh")
    forget_gate = mx.sym.Activation(slice_gates[2], act_type="sigmoid")
    out_gate = mx.sym.Activation(slice_gates[3], act_type="sigmoid")
    next_c = (forget_gate * prev_state.c) + (in_gate * in_transform)
    next_h = out_gate * mx.sym.Activation(next_c, act_type="tanh")
    return LSTMState(c=next_c, h=next_h)

''' one layer lstm '''    
def lstm_layer(inputs, num_hidden, name, dropout=0.):

    layer_param = LSTMParam(i2h_weight=mx.sym.Variable("%s_i2h_weight" % name),
                            i2h_bias=mx.sym.Variable("%s_i2h_bias" % name),
                            h2h_weight=mx.sym.Variable("%s_h2h_weight" % name),
                            h2h_bias=mx.sym.Variable("%s_h2h_bias" % name))

    prev_state = LSTMState(c=mx.sym.Variable("%s_init_c" % name),
                           h=mx.sym.Variable("%s_init_h" % name))                            

    layer_out = []
    for i in range(len(inputs)):
        next_state = lstm_cell(inputs[i], prev_state, layer_param, num_hidden, i, name, dropout)
        prev_state = next_state
        layer_out.append(next_state.h)

    return layer_out

''' lstm init_states for data iterator '''
def lstm_layer_init_states(batch_size, num_hidden, name):
    init_c = ('%s_init_c'%name, (batch_size, num_hidden))
    init_h = ('%s_init_h'%name, (batch_size, num_hidden))
    return [init_c, init_h]

''' mxnet interface batch '''
class simple_batch(object):
    def __init__(self, data_names, data, label_names, label, bucket_key):
        self.data = data
        self.label = label
        self.data_names = data_names
        self.label_names = label_names
        self.bucket_key = bucket_key

    @property
    def provide_data(self):
        return [(n, x.shape) for n, x in zip(self.data_names, self.data)]

    @property
    def provide_label(self):
        return [(n, x.shape) for n, x in zip(self.label_names, self.label)]

class simple_data_iterator(mx.io.DataIter):
    def __init__(self, init_states, data_name='data', label_name='label',
                 fea_len=257, bucket_num=10, batch_size=10, order='ascend', max_seq_len=500):

        self.init_states = init_states
        self.data_name = data_name
        self.label_name = label_name
        self.fea_len = fea_len
        self.bucket_num = bucket_num
        self.batch_size = batch_size
        self.order = order
        self.max_seq_len = max_seq_len

        ''' for buckets '''
        self.buckets = np.linspace(1, max_seq_len, num=bucket_num, dtype='int32')
        self.bucket_indices = np.arange(len(self.buckets))
        if order is 'descend':
            self.bucket_indices = self.bucket_indices[::-1]

        ''' for mxnet interface '''
        self.init_states = init_states
        self.init_state_arrays = [mx.nd.zeros(x[1]) for x in init_states]
        self.init_state_names = [x[0] for x in self.init_states]
        self.default_bucket_key = self.buckets[0]
        self.provide_data = [('%s_t%d' % (self.data_name, t), (batch_size, fea_len))
                             for t in range(self.default_bucket_key)] + init_states
        self.provide_label = [('%s_t%d' % (self.label_name, t), (batch_size, fea_len))
                              for t in range(self.default_bucket_key)]

        ''' for next() '''
        self.bucket_load_idx = 0

    def reset(self):
        if self.order is 'random':
            np.random.shuffle(self.bucket_indices)
        self.bucket_load_idx = 0

    def next(self):
        if self.bucket_load_idx >= len(self.bucket_indices):
            raise StopIteration
        else:
            bucket_key = self.buckets[self.bucket_indices[self.bucket_load_idx]]
            print bucket_key
            random_label = np.ones((bucket_key, self.batch_size*self.fea_len), dtype='float32')            
            random_data = random_label + np.random.normal(size=((bucket_key, self.batch_size*self.fea_len)))

            data_all = [mx.nd.array(random_data[t,:].reshape((self.batch_size, self.fea_len))) \
                        for t in range(bucket_key)] + self.init_state_arrays
            label_all = [mx.nd.array(random_label[t,:].reshape((self.batch_size, self.fea_len))) \
                        for t in range(bucket_key)]
            data_names = ['%s_t%d' % (self.data_name, t) for t in range(bucket_key)] + self.init_state_names
            label_names = ['%s_t%d' % (self.label_name, t) for t in range(bucket_key)]

            batch = simple_batch(data_names, data_all, label_names, label_all, bucket_key)

            self.bucket_load_idx += 1
            return batch

    def __next__(self):
        return self.next(self)

    def __iter__(self):
        return self


if __name__ == '__main__':
    gpus = [0]
    batch_size = 30

    # set bucket order: can be set to 'ascend', 'descend', 'random'
    order = 'descend'
    bucket_num = 40
    max_seq_len = 240
    do_val = False

    learning_rate = 0.001
    momentum = 0.9
    weight_decay = 0.00001

    num_epoch = 30

    fea_len = 257
    input_name = 'data'
    label_name = 'label'

    ''' define network: sym_gen and get_init_states '''
    num_hidden1 = 256
    num_hidden2 = 256
    num_hidden3 = 256

    def sym_gen(seq_len):
        reg_weight = mx.sym.Variable('reg_weight')
        reg_bias = mx.sym.Variable('reg_bias')        
        input_sym = [mx.sym.Variable('%s_t%d' % (input_name, t)) for t in range(seq_len)]
        label_sym = [mx.sym.Variable('%s_t%d' % (label_name, t)) for t in range(seq_len)]        
        label_concat = mx.sym.Concat(*label_sym, dim=0, name='label_concat')

        lstm1 = lstm_layer(input_sym, num_hidden1, 'lstm1')
        lstm2 = lstm_layer(lstm1, num_hidden2, 'lstm2')
        lstm3 = lstm_layer(lstm2, num_hidden3, 'lstm3')

        lstm_out_concat = mx.sym.Concat(*lstm3, dim=0, name='lstm_out_concat')
        fc = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=lstm_out_concat, 
                                   weight=reg_weight, 
                                   bias=reg_bias, 
                                   num_hidden=fea_len,
                                   name='fc')
        reg_all = mx.sym.LinearRegressionOutput(data=fc, label=label_concat, name='reg_all')
        reg_slice = mx.sym.SliceChannel(reg_all, num_outputs=seq_len, axis=0, name='reg_slice')
        return reg_slice

    def get_init_states():
        lstm1_init_states = lstm_layer_init_states(batch_size, num_hidden1, 'lstm1')
        lstm2_init_states = lstm_layer_init_states(batch_size, num_hidden2, 'lstm2')
        lstm3_init_states = lstm_layer_init_states(batch_size, num_hidden3, 'lstm3')
        return lstm1_init_states + lstm2_init_states + lstm3_init_states

    symbol = sym_gen
    init_states = get_init_states()

    ''' prepare data '''
    train_iterator = simple_data_iterator(init_states,
                                          fea_len=fea_len,
                                          bucket_num=bucket_num, 
                                          batch_size=batch_size,
                                          max_seq_len=max_seq_len,
                                          order=order)
    if do_val:                                      
        val_iterator = simple_data_iterator(init_states,
                                            fea_len=fea_len,
                                            bucket_num=bucket_num, 
                                            batch_size=batch_size,
                                            max_seq_len=max_seq_len,
                                            order=order)
    else:
        val_iterator = None                                        

    ''' training '''
    contexts = [mx.context.gpu(i) for i in gpus]

    optimizer = mx.optimizer.SGD(learning_rate=learning_rate,
                                 momentum=momentum,
                                 wd=weight_decay,
                                 clip_gradient=1) 

    initializer = mx.initializer.Xavier(factor_type='in',magnitude=3)

    model = mx.model.FeedForward(symbol=symbol, 
                                 ctx=contexts,
                                 num_epoch=num_epoch,
                                 optimizer=optimizer,
                                 initializer=initializer)

    import logging
    head = '%(asctime)-15s %(message)s'
    logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG, format=head)

    model.fit(X=train_iterator, eval_data=val_iterator, eval_metric='mse',
              batch_end_callback = mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 1)) 
```
- The memory usage results are:

| max_seq_len=120 | order=descend | order=ascend |
| --- | --- | --- |
| bucket_num=20 | 395 | 461 |
| bucket_num=40 | 395 | 597 |
| bucket_num=60 | 395 | 720 |

| max_seq_len=240 | order=descend | order=ascend |
| --- | --- | --- |
| bucket_num=20 | 575 | 723 |
| bucket_num=40 | 608 | 1053 |
| bucket_num=60 | 596 | 1320 |

| max_seq_len=360 | order=descend | order=ascend |
| --- | --- | --- |
| bucket_num=20 | 790 | 1011 |
| bucket_num=40 | 790 | 1468 |
| bucket_num=60 | 823 | 1917 |
- here is the figure:

`order = descend`:
![descend](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18130064/14462577/4f3a4774-00fa-11e6-82f7-fa52bab3e2b6.png)

`order = ascend`:
![ascend](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18130064/14462579/56a29b1a-00fa-11e6-8801-0e983b8b0636.png)
- It seems that when `order = ascend`, memory usage increases at python/executor_manager.py in `_bind_exec()` at this line:

``` python
executor = sym.bind(ctx=ctx, args=arg_arrays, args_grad=grad_arrays,
                        aux_states=aux_arrays,
                        grad_req=grad_req, shared_exec=base_exec)
```

A guess about the design principle of is_train is that, if is_train is set to True, the intermediate results of intermediate layers will not be saved and if is_train is set to False, the intermediate results will be saved. This design principle could save memory, because forward computation doesn't need to save the intermediate results?
Is the guess right?

One possible reason is that by default, when constructing the optimizer, we further divide the learning rate by mini-batch size. So that might be why your updates looks "bigger".

BTW: with the new module API, it is now less complicated to manually create a data batch and then call forward / backward / update manually. See [the example](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/module/mnist_mlp.py#L30) here.

@GrindstoneLZX Thanks for the detailed test case. After inserting some print statements into `_bind_exec()` as

``` patch
diff --git a/python/mxnet/executor_manager.py b/python/mxnet/executor_manager.py
index 6f5fcfd..628f0aa 100644
--- a/python/mxnet/executor_manager.py
```

My best guess is that nvidia-smi is not very accurate at counting memory when you increasingly allocate a bunch of relative small memory blocks. Or @tqchen @antinucleon do we have a customized memory allocator for `NDArray` that might not be very optimized under this situation?

Good idea, I guess that makes the history cleaner.

In current implementation, the memory will always be reused from the executor binded from default key. We need to make sure that the default key uses the maximum length. Otherwise the other executors will grab more memory
We can possibly use two different modules for LSTM and cnn, as what @pluskid did in #1787
Yes, kvstore can be None only when you are using one device as @Godricly suggested
Let us keep things as it is as it is already merged in and it could be a bad idea to squash things in the main repo. Just keep things in mind next time
is_train was not related to memory saving, but will only affect some runtime behavior of operators. Currently it is mainly for things like dropout and batchnorm
I think the html was set intentionally by @mli However, eventually they should be indeed fixed to .md suffix and recommonmark should be able to translate the URL

@Viswa14 sorry for late replay, you may use pdb to debug the return value of offset(), and make sure it is corretly for your symbol. on the other hand, i think your symbol define maybe wrong for the deconvotion kernel/stride paramter in fcnxs_score, be careful to check the kernel/stride for your use.

In @tqchen 's particular LSTM model parallel example, it seems it is using a slightly unconventional way to represent the data. Each row is a time-step in a mini-batch. So each column is sentence (marked with `eos` for new sentences) -- checkout `set_rnn_inputs`.

In the other LSTM examples, especially the ones using high-level model API, since the data for each index is fed separately, it does not really matter originally it is in row order or column order. In a recent PR  #1833 we are refactoring this by having the convention that a mini-batch of sentence is of the shape `(batch-size, seq-len)`.

model = mx.model.FeedForward(
        ctx                = devs,
        symbol             = network,
        num_epoch          = args.num_epochs,
        learning_rate      = args.lr,

You can do that, for example:

import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np

// define net 
data = mx.symbol.Variable(name='data')
conv1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv1', data=data , num_filter=64, kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1))
conv2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv2', data=conv1 , num_filter=64, kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1))

arg_names = conv2.list_arguments()
print arg_names
// ['data', 'conv1_weight', 'conv1_bias', 'conv2_weight', 'conv2_bias']

// infer network parameters shape and output shape
arg_shape, out_shape, aux_shape = conv2.infer_shape(data=(1, 3, 100, 100))
arg_dict = dict(zip(arg_names, [mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx=mx.cpu()) for shape in arg_shape]))

// then you can init each layer with what ever you like
arg_dict['conv1_weight'][:] = np.random.uniform(-0.1, 0.1, arg_dict['conv1_weight'].shape) 

arg_dict['conv2_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 1, arg_dict['conv2_weight'].shape) 

// last step
// Bind the Symbols with NDArray and Run
executor = conv2.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args=arg_dict)

more details:
http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/tutorial.html

I resolved this issue by looking at the size of each output layer with `infer_shape`, ex. 

`arg_shape, output_shape, aux_shape = conv1.infer_shape(data=(1,3,224,224))`
`print output_shape`

If you look at the size given in the paper, the lines that you need to change is 
`conv1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, kernel=(7,7), stride=(2,2), num_filter=96, pad=(2,2))`
and
`conv10 = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=dropout_fire9, kernel=(1,1), num_filter=num_classes)`
